sen.j: 茜部荘（あかなべのしょう）は、平安時代～室町時代にかけて美濃国にあった荘園。
sen.e: Akanabe-no-sho Estate was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.
Akanabe-no-sho Manor was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.
Akanabe-no-sho Manor was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Mino Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.

sen.j: もと厚見荘（あつみのしょう）。
sen.e: It was originally called Atsumi-no-sho.
It was originally called Atsumi-no-sho.
It was originally called Atsumi-no-sho.
It was an estate of Todai-ji Temple.
It was an estate of Todai-ji Temple.
It was an estate of Todai-ji Temple.
The southern part of Atsumi Country, Mino Province.
The southern part of Atsumi Country, Mino Province.
The southern part of Atsumi Country, Mino Province.

sen.j: 現在の岐阜県岐阜市茜部地区（茜部大野、茜部中島、茜部菱野、茜部新所、茜部寺屋敷など）が中心地。
sen.e: Its center corresponds to today's Akanabe area（Akanabe-ono, Akanabe-nakashima, Akanabe-hishino, Akanabe-shinsho, Akanabe-terayashiki, etc.), in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture.
Its center corresponds to today's Akanabe area （Akanabe-ono, Akanabe-nakashima, Akanabe-hishino, Akanabe-shinsho, Akanabe-terayashiki, etc.) in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture.
sen.cmt: スペースを補足不必要なコンマを削除
sen.e: Its center corresponds to today's Akanabe area （Akanabe-ono, Akanabe-nakashima, Akanabe-hishino, Akanabe-shinsho, Akanabe-terayashiki, etc.) in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture.
About 111.71ha, as of the year 818.
About 111.71ha, as of the year 818.
About 111.71ha, as of the year 818.
Origin
Origin
Origin

sen.j: もとは桓武天皇の勅旨田で、大同 (日本)4年（809年）2月21日に立荘。
sen.e: It was originally a Chokushiden (proprietorships and imperial land) of Emperor Kammu, and in February 21, 809, it was established as a shoen.
It was originally a chokushiden (imperial proprietorships and land) of Emperor Kammu, and was established as a shoen on February 21, 809.
sen.cmt: 読みやすくするように再構成「in」→「on」
sen.e: It was originally a chokushiden (imperial proprietorships and land) of Emperor Kammu, and was established as a shoen on March 14, 809.

sen.j: 桓武天皇は皇女・朝原内親王に譲渡し、弘仁9年3月27日に彼女の遺命により、その母の酒人内親王によって東大寺に寄進された。
sen.e: Emperor Kammu transferred it to his daughter, Imperial Princess Asahara, and in May 9, 818, according to her dead will, the land was donated to Todai-ji Temple by her mother, Imperial Princess Sakahito.
Emperor Kammu transferred it to his daughter, Imperial Princess Asahara, and on May 9, 818, the land was donated to Todai-ji Temple by her mother, Imperial Princess Sakahito, according to her will.
Emperor Kammu transferred it to his daughter, Imperial Princess Asahara, and on May 9, 818, the land was donated to Todai-ji Temple by her mother, Imperial Princess Sakahito, according to her will.

sen.j: 東大寺領となった後、天長7年（830年）、宇佐八幡宮を勧請し茜部神社（延喜式神名帳）が創建されたという。
sen.e: It is said that after it was converted into the territory of Todai-ji Temple, Akanabe Shrine （Jinmeicho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers）) was constructed by calling on a deity for making a branch shrine of 宇佐八幡宮Usa Hachiman-gu Shrine in the manor,

It is said that after the manor became the territory of Todai-ji Temple, Akanabe-jinja Shrine (listed in the Jinmyocho (list of deities) of the Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers)) was founded in the year 830 by the ceremonial transfer of the divided tutelary deity of Usa Hachiman-gu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 「was converted to」→「became」「-jinja」を補足「listed in the」を補足「Jinmeicho」→「Jinmyocho」「the」を削除「the」を補足「constructed」→「founded」原文を反映するように、用語集の用語共有データベースを基に文の後半を書き直しました
sen.e: It is said that after the manor became the territory of Todai-ji Temple, Akanabe-jinja Shrine (listed in the Jinmyocho (list of deities) of the Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers)) was founded in the year 830 by the ceremonial transfer of the divided tutelary deity of Usa Hachiman-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 天徳 (日本)4年（960年）には厚見荘から茜部荘に改称されている。
sen.e: In 960, the manor's name was changed from Atsumi-no-sho to Akanabe-no-sho.
In 960, the manor's name was changed from Atsumi-no-sho to Akanabe-no-sho.
In 960, the manor's name was changed from Atsumi-no-sho to Akanabe-no-sho.
Todai-ji Temple
Todai-ji Temple
Todai-ji Temple

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に大江広元の子の長井時広が地頭になり、代々これを相続、東大寺と訴訟を繰り返して勢力を拡大するが、南北朝時代 (日本)に後醍醐天皇が没収し、東大寺に再寄進した。
sen.e: Since the time when OE no Hiromoto's son, Tokihiro NAGAI became jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided) during the Kamakura Period, the Nagai family had handed down this post for generations, and gradually expanded its control over the manor, by repeatedly filing a suite against Todai-ji Temple, but during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, Emperor Godaigo, who confiscated the manor at one time, donated it anew to Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 地頭→jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided) [http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/jito]
sen.e: Since the time when OE no Hiromoto's son, Tokihiro NAGAI, became jito (manager and lord of a manor) during the Kamakura Period, the Nagai family had handed down the post down through successive generations and gradually expanded its control over the manor through repeated legal action against Todai-ji Temple, but Emperor Godaigo confiscated the manor during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and redonated it to Todai-ji Temple.

Since the time when OE no Hiromoto's son, Tokihiro NAGAI, became jito (manager and lord of a manor) during the Kamakura Period, the Nagai family had handed down the post down through successive generations and gradually expanded its control over the manor through repeated legal action against Todai-ji Temple, but Emperor Godaigo confiscated the manor during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts and redonated it to Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: その後の地頭は不明だが、応仁の乱の頃には完全に東大寺のもとを離れた。
sen.e: The details of the successive jitos since then are unknown, but the manor had became completely outside the control of Todai-ji Temple by the time when the Onin War took place.
The details of the successive jito who served since this time are unknown, but the manor had become completely outside of the control of Todai-ji Temple by the time of the Onin War.
sen.cmt: 「jitos」→「jito」（ローマ字化日本語に「s」をつけない」「who served]を追加「then」→「this time」「became」→「become」「of」を追加「when the Onin War took place」→「of the Onin War」
sen.e: The details of the successive jito who served since this time are unknown, but the manor had become completely outside of the control of Todai-ji Temple by the time of the Onin War.

sen.j: 年貢は東大寺の衣服料にあてたため、絹や綿で収めた。
sen.e: As nengu (land tax), silk and cotton were supplied to cover the clothing costs of Todai-ji Temple.
The nengu (land tax) was collected in the form of silk and cotton to cover the clothing costs of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 原文を反映するように再構成しました
sen.e: The nengu (land tax) was collected in the form of silk and cotton to cover the clothing costs of Todai-ji Temple.
